signs: All parts of the plant have toxic potential, although the possibility of serious effects is usually limited to ingestions of large quantities. Consuming Oxalis species can produce colic in horses, and kidney failure is possible if significant amounts are eaten.

name: Groundsel
signs: The plant is not very palatable, but will be eaten by animals with no other forage; poisonings typically occur from ingestion of green plant material or material in hay. The toxic components can cause liver failure, referred to as "walking disease" or "sleepy staggers". Signs include weight loss, weakness, sleepiness, yawning, incoordination, yellowish discoloration to mucous membranes (icterus), neurologic problems secondary to liver failure (aimless walking, chewing motions, head pressing). Animals may appear to be normal at first, then become suddenly affected; the syndrome progresses rapidly over a few days to a week. Liver damage, depression, anorexia, vomiting, diarrhea, muddy mucous membranes, weakness, ataxia.

name: Larkspur
signs: Unless there is a lack of suitable forage, horses typically do not consume toxic amounts of larkspur. The toxicity of the plant may vary depending on seasonal changes and field conditions; as the plant matures, it generally becomes less toxic. The alkaloids in the plant cause neuromuscular paralysis; clinical effects include constipation, colic, increased salivation, muscle tremors, stiffness, weakness, recumbency, and convulsions. Cardiac failure may occur, as can death from respiratory paralysis.

signs: Oral irritation, intense burning and irritation of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting, difficulty swallowing.

name: Maleberry
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, depression, cardiovascular collapse, hypersalivation, weakness, coma, low blood pressure, death. Ingestion of a few leaves can cause serious problems.

name: Mapleleaf Begonia
signs: Kidney failure (in grazing animals), vomiting, salivation in dogs/cats. Most toxic part is underground.

name: Marijuana
signs: Prolonged depression, vomiting, incoordination, sleepiness or excitation, hypersalivaton, dilated pupils, low blood pressure, low body temperature, seizure, coma, death (rare)

name: Marjoram
signs: Vomiting and diarrhea

name: Mauna Loa Peace Lily
signs: Oral irritation, pain and swelling of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting (not horses), difficulty swallowing

name: Mayapple
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, panting, coma (rare); dermal - redness, skin ulcers.

name: Mayweed
signs: Contact dermatitis, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, allergic reactions. Long term use can lead to bleeding tendencies.
description: Volatile oil; bisabolol, chamazulene, anthemic acid, tannic acid

name: Meadow Saffron
signs: oral irritation, bloody vomiting, diarrhea, shock, multi-organ damage, bone marrow suppression.

name: Medicine Plant
signs: Vomiting, change in urine color (red)

name: Metallic Leaf Begonia
signs: Kidney failure (in grazing animals), vomiting, salivation in dogs/cats. Most toxic part is underground.

name: Mexican Breadfruit
signs: Oral irritation, intense burning and irritation of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting, difficulty swallowing.

name: Milfoil
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, depression, anorexia, hypersalivation

name: Milkweed
signs: Vomiting, profound depression, weakness, anorexia, and diarrhea are common; may be followed by seizures, difficulty breathing, rapid, weak pulse, dilated pupils, kidney or liver failure, coma, respiratory paralysis and death
description: Some species contain cardiotoxins (steroidal glycosidic cardenolides) and other species contain neurotoxins.

name: Mint
signs: Vomiting and diarrhea with large ingestions

name: Mistletoe "American"
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, low blood pressure (rare), difficulty breathing, low heart rate

name: Mock Azalea
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, depression, irregular heart beat, death

name: Mole Bean Plant
signs: Access to ornamental plants or pruned foliage most common in poisonings. Ricin is a highly toxic component that inhibits protein synthesis; ingestion of as little as one ounce of seeds can be lethal. Signs typically develop 12 to 48 hours after ingestion, and include loss of appetite, excessive thirst, weakness, colic, trembling, sweating, loss of coordination, difficulty breathing, progressive central nervous system depression, and fever. As syndrome progresses, bloody diarrhea may occur, and convulsions and coma can precede death.

name: Morning Glory
signs: Vomiting, large amounts of seeds may cause hallucinations
description: Indole alkaloids (Lysergic acid, lysergamide, elymoclavine and chanoclavine)

name: Morning-Noon-and-Night
signs: Tremors, seizures (for several days), diarrhea, vomiting, hypersalivation, lethargy, incoordination, coughing

name: Moss Rose
signs: Kidney failure (rare in dogs/cats), tremors, salivation.

name: Mother of Millions
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, abnormal heart rhythm (rare).

name: Mother-in-Law
signs: Oral irritation, intense burning and irritation of the mouth, lips, tongue, excessive drooling, vomiting, difficulty in swallowing.

name: Mother-In-Law Plant
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, abnormal heart rhythm (rare).

name: Mother-in-Law’s Tongue
signs: Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea.

name: Mum
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, hypersalivation, incoordination, dermatitis
description: Sesquiterpene, lactones, pyrethrins and other potential irritants

name: Naked Lady
signs: Vomiting (not horses), depression, diarrhea, abdominal pain, hypersalivation, anorexia, tremors.

name: Nandina
signs: Weakness, incoordination, seizures, coma, respiratory failure, death (rare in pets).

name: Narcissus
signs: Vomiting, salvation, diarrhea; large ingestions cause convulsions, low blood pressure, tremors and cardiac arrhythmias. Bulbs are the most poisonous part.

name: Nasturtium (Watercress)
signs: Mild vomiting and diarrhea

name: Needlepoint Ivy
signs: Vomiting, abdominal pain, hypersalivation, diarrhea. Foliage is more toxic than berries

name: Nephthytis
signs: Oral irritation, pain and swelling of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting (not horses), difficulty swallowing

name: Nicotiana
signs: Hyperexcitability then depression, vomiting, incoordination, paralysis, death is possible.

name: Nightshade
signs: Hypersalivation, inappetence, severe gastrointestinal upset, diarrhea, drowsiness, CNS depression, confusion, behavioral change, weakness, dilated pupils, slow heart rate.

name: Octopus Tree
signs: Mild vomiting, diarrhea.

name: Oilcloth Flower
signs: Oral irritation, intense burning and irritation of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting, difficulty swallowing

name: Oleander
signs: Drooling, abdominal pain, diarrhea, colic, depression, death

name: Onion
signs: Vomiting, breakdown of red blood cells (hemolytic anemia, Heinz body anemia), blood in urine, weakness, high heart rate, panting

name: Orange
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, depression; potential dermatitis. Fruit is edible, skins and plant material can cause problems.

name: Oregano
signs: Mild vomiting and diarrhea

name: Oregon Holly
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea and depression. Leaves and berries are low toxicity.

name: Ornamental Pepper

name: Parsley
signs: Photosensitization (sunburn, dermatitis), large amounts are needed to cause this effect

signs: Kidney failure (in grazing animals), vomiting, salivation in dogs/cats. Most toxic part is underground.

name: Peace Lily

name: Peacock Flower
signs: Vomiting and diarrhea.

name: Pencil Cactus

signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, depression

name: Perennial Pea
signs: Weakness, lethargy, pacing, head pressing, tremors, seizures and possibly death.

name: Periwinkle
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, low blood pressure, depression, tremors, seizures, coma, death.

signs: Oral irritation, pain and swelling of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting (not horses), difficulty swallowing

name: Plum
signs: Stems, leaves, seeds contain cyanide, particularly toxic in the process of wilting

name: Plumosa Fern
signs: Allergic dermatitis with repeated dermal exposure. Berry ingestion could result in gastric upset (vomiting, abdominal pain, or diarrhea).

name: Poinciana
signs: Intense burning and irritation of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting, diarrhea, difficulty swallowing, incoordination (rare)

name: Poinsettia
signs: Irritating to the mouth and stomach, sometimes causing vomiting, but generally over-rated in toxicity.

name: Poison Daisy

name: Poison Parsnip
signs: Diarrhea, seizures, tremors, extreme stomach pain, dilated pupils, fever, bloat, respiratory depression, and death.

name: Portulaca
signs: Muscle weakness, depression, diarrhea

name: Prayer Bean
signs: Severe vomiting and diarrhea (sometimes bloody), tremors, high heart rate, fever, shock, death. Seeds are very toxic (seed coat must be broken).
description: Abrin (lectin or a toxalbumin) and abric acid (a glycoside)

name: Pride-of-India
signs: Diarrhea, vomiting, salivation, depression, weakness, and seizures. Ripe fruit (berries) most toxic but also bark, leaves, and flowers.

name: Primrose
signs: Mild vomiting

name: Privet
signs: Gastrointestinal upset (most common), incoordination, increased heart rate, death (rare).

name: Queensland Nut
signs: Dogs

name: Racemose asparagus
signs: allergic dermatitis with repeated dermal exposure. Berry ingestion could result in gastric upset (vomiting, abdominal pain, or diarrhea.)

name: Ragwort
signs: The plant is not very palatable, but will be eaten by animals with no other forage; poisonings typically occur from ingestion of green plant material or material in hay. The toxic components can cause liver failure, referred to as "walking disease" or "sleepy staggers". Signs include weight loss, weakness, sleepiness, yawning, incoordination, yellowish discoloration to mucous membranes (icterus), neurologic problems secondary to liver failure (aimless walking, chewing motions, head pressing). Animals may appear to be normal at first, then become suddenly affected; the syndrome progresses rapidly over a few days to a week. Liver damage, depression, anorexia, vomiting, diarrhea, muddy mucous membranes, weakness, ataxia.

name: Ranger's Button
signs: Photosensitization (sunburn, dermatitis), large amounts are needed to cause this effect

name: Red Emerald
signs: Oral irritation, intense burning and irritation of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting, difficulty swallowing.

name: Red Princess
signs: Oral irritation, intense burning and irritation of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting, difficulty swallowing.

name: Red-Marginated Dracaena
signs: In cats

name: Rex Begonia
signs: Kidney failure (in grazing animals), vomiting, salivation in dogs/cats. Most toxic part is underground.

name: Rhododendron
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, hypersalivation, weakness, coma, hypotension, CNS depression, cardiovascular collapse and death. Ingestion of a few leaves can cause serious problems. Rhododendron is typically not very palatable to horses unless it is the only forage available, but sheep and goats may graze readily on the plant. The toxic principle interferes with normal skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle and nerve function. Clinical effects typically occur within a few hours after ingestion, and can include acute digestive upset, excessive drooling, loss of appetite, frequent bowel movements/diarrhea, colic, depression, weakness, loss of coordination, stupor, leg paralysis, weak heart rate and recumbency for 2 or more days; at this point, improvement may be seen or the animal may become comatose and die.

name: Rhubarb
signs: Kidney failure, tremors, salivation.

name: Ribbon Plant
signs: Vomiting (occasionally with blood), depression, anorexia, hypersalivation, dilated pupils (cats).

name: Ridderstjerne
signs: Vomiting, salvation, diarrhea; large ingestions cause convulsions, low blood pressure, tremors and cardiac arrhythmias. Bulbs are the most poisonous part.

name: Roman Chamomile
signs: Contact dermatitis, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, allergic reactions. Long term use can lead to bleeding tendencies.
description: Volatile oil; bisabolol, chamazulene, anthemic acid, tannic acid

name: Rosebay
signs: Vomiting, diarrhea, hypersalivation, weakness, coma, hypotension, CNS depression, cardiovascular collapse and death. Ingestion of a few leaves can cause serious problems. Rhododendron is typically not very palatable to horses unless it is the only forage available, but sheep and goats may graze readily on the plant. The toxic principle interferes with normal skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle and nerve function. Clinical effects typically occur within a few hours after ingestion, and can include acute digestive upset, excessive drooling, loss of appetite, frequent bowel movements/diarrhea, colic, depression, weakness, loss of coordination, stupor, leg paralysis, weak heart rate and recumbency for 2 or more days; at this point, improvement may be seen or the animal may become comatose and die.

name: Sago Palm

signs: Oral irritation, pain and swelling of mouth, tongue and lips, excessive drooling, vomiting (not horses), difficulty swallowing

name: Sorrel
signs: Small exposures only result in GI upset. Very large amounts can cause weakness, muscle fasciculations, and potentially seizures from hypocalcemia. Hypocalcemia can also result in arrhythmias. Secondary renal injury may also develop from the crystals. This is only expected in massive exposures or with chronic ingestion
